title: Effects of Different Sources of Dietary Protein on Markers of Kidney Function in Individuals With Diabetes, Prediabetes, and Healthy Persons: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

sections.results:
Twelve
RCTs were included, of which 11 (involving 228 participants) were compiled in
meta-analyses of random-effects models. Interventions consisted of diets emphasiz-
ing plant or white meat protein, with reduced intake of animal or red meat protein.
Pooled data from crossover trials (n¼8) favored intervention diets for urinary albu-
min excretion (ratio of means, 0.86; 95% confidence interval 0.80 to 0.94; I
2 ¼ 4%)
and glomerular filtration rate (ratio of means, 0.90; 95% confidence interval 0.87 to
0.94; I
2 ¼ 45%), compared with control diets. Results from parallel-design studies
(n ¼3), however, were not statistically significant for any outcome. The quality of
the evidence ranged from very low to moderate, and most studies were judged
with at least some concerns in terms of risk of bias.
sections.conclusion:
This meta-
analysis found weak evidence for small to moderate improvements in markers of
kidney function in favor of interventions with lower animal protein (or red meat
protein) compared with usual diets in short-term crossover trials. These findings re-
quire confirmation in well-designed randomized controlled trials.

sections.introduction:
Diabetes mellitus is a very common chronic disease, for
which the estimated global prevalence in 2019 was
9.3%, of which half (50.1%) were unaware of their con-
dition.
1 One of the most serious consequences of diabe-
tes is chronic exposure to hyperglycemia, a condition
associated with several microvascular complications
(eg, kidney disease and retinopathy). The prevalence of
chronic kidney disease (CKD) in individuals with dia-
betes ranges approximately from 20% to 40%, making it
the leading cause of end-stage renal disease in many
countries.
2,3
The early stages of diabetic kidney disease (DKD)
are typically associated with at least one of the following
scenarios: abnormally high excretion of urinary albu-
min (/C21 30 mg/g creatinine) in the presence of otherwise
normal renal function, and/or a gradual progressive de-
crease in the estimated glomerular filtration rate
(eGFR),
4 either or both of which commonly develops
after an initial hyperfiltrating stage.5 Such conditions
are not merely markers of disease but have also been
demonstrated to be valid surrogate end points associ-
ated with several clinically relevant outcomes.
6
Currently available therapies that are thought to de-
lay the progression of DKD have been mostly restricted
to optimization of glucose control and the use of blood-
pressure–lowering drugs (eg, angiotensin II receptor
blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibi-
tors).
7 It has been argued that most agents have been
only modestly effective, as most patients continue to
progress in the long term,
8 although recent trials have
convincingly shown nephroprotective effects of SGLT2
inhibitors in patients with or without diabetes in pre-
venting CKD progression.
9–11 Yet, evidence of a recent
rise in the incidence of DKD further highlights the need
to identify and implement novel and cost-effective ther-
apeutic strategies in addition to pharmacological
interventions.
12
Dietary interventions such as protein restriction
have long been investigated due to their potential for
secondary prevention of CKD, with purported benefits
in terms of uremia control, reduced kidney stone for-
mation, and preservation of residual renal function.
13
However, it is still unclear whether limiting protein in-
take is effective in reducing or slowing progression to
end-stage kidney disease, as the evidence suggests there
is only a small benefit in a select patient population
with mild CKD, and a lack of effect in patients with
more severe CKD.
14 In addition, clinicians often face a
dilemma in weighing the risks of malnutrition and of
worsening of sarcopenia in obese and/or patients with
diabetes.
15–17 In fact, the American Diabetes
Association (ADA) does not endorse reducing the
amount of dietary protein below the recommended
daily allowance (0.8 g/kg/day) for nondialysis-
dependent patients, as doing so has not been associated
with significant benefits in the course of decline in esti-
mated GFR.
4,14
An alternative dietary approach to protein restric-
tion that may beneficially regulate renal function is to
modify the type of protein consumed. Observational
studies suggest that plant protein diets may be more
protective than animal protein diets for incident cases
of CKD, and diets higher in animal protein have been
associated with greater decreases in eGFR.
18,19 In addi-
tion, experimental studies in patients with or without
diabetes have shown that the effects of dietary protein
levels on renal hemodynamics may differ depending on
the source of dietary protein,
20–22 either comparing
diets based on white meat (chicken or fish) with those
based on red meat,
23 or diets based on soy compared
with habitual diets .24 However, no consensus regarding
the efficacy of such interventions has so far been estab-
lished. Thus, the current systematic review and meta-
analysis aimed to evaluate the effects of different sour-
ces of dietary protein on kidney function parameters in
patients with diabetes.
sections.methods:
Study design
This systematic review of randomized controlled trials
(RCTs) was conducted according to the recommenda-
tions of the latest Cochrane Handbook for Systematic
Reviews of Interventions
25 and followed the Preferred
Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-
Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines.
26 A protocol for this sys-
tematic review was pre-registered on PROSPERO (CRD
no. 42020154671).
Research question
The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the
available evidence from RCTs for the following clinical
question: “What is the effect of changing the predomi-
nant type of dietary protein found in a person’s usual
diet to another type of dietary protein, on markers of
kidney function in individuals with diabetes mellitus?”
In the meta-analyses, we defined 2 different Patient,
Intervention, Comparators, Outcome and Study designs
(PICOS) for each synthesis (Cochrane Handbook,
Chapter 9): (1) in order to assess the effect of any
change in protein type from that in a person’s usual
diet, the experimental groups were defined as any inter-
vention that aimed to replace at least some amount of
animal protein (or red meat protein, if the intervention

arm consisted of white meat protein) with any other
type of protein (eg, plant protein or soy protein); and
(2) in order to assess the effects of specific types of pro-
tein, it was planned to perform subgroup analyses of
studies using identical types of protein as the predomi-
nant protein source in the intervention arms, compared
to usual diets (further described in the Methods sec-
tion). For both PICOs, control groups were pragmati-
cally usual diets, with protein type predominantly based
on animal sources.
Eligibility criteria
Inclusion and exclusion criteria were developed using
the Patient, Intervention, Comparators, Outcome and
Study Design (PICOS) method and are presented in
Table 1. Any type of randomized controlled trial was el-
igible, whether of parallel or crossover design, that com-
pared the effects of interventions predominantly based
on different sources of dietary protein reporting at least
one of the primary outcomes: (A) GFR or (B) urinary
albumin excretion (UAE). The population of interest
was adults over 18 years of age with a diagnosis of dia-
betes mellitus. The clinical trials had to compare diets
with regards to different sources, but not quantities, of
dietary protein.
Studies comparing different amounts of dietary
protein between study arms and acute postprandial
experiments were excluded, as well as studies investigat-
ing the effects of supplements rather than the effects of
a diet predominantly based on a specific type of protein.
However, the use of supplements as a means of increas-
ing the consumption of some type of dietary protein
over another was not judged as a reason for exclusion.
Moreover, observational studies, literature reviews,
opinion papers, nonrandomized trials, and abstracts
with irretrievable full text after 2 attempts to contact the
authors were also excluded.
Search methods for identification of studies
Studies were identified through a comprehensive search
strategy developed and conducted by I.E. and F.M.S. in
the following electronic databases on December 4, 2019:
MEDLINE (PubMed), EMBASE, and Scopus. There
were no restrictions with respect to language or date of
publication. The selection of terms for the search strat-
egy was based on MeSH terms (PubMed) and several
variations of the following main key words in all data-
bases: diabetes (population); dietary proteins, plant,
vegetable, soy, meat, and diet (interventions); GFR, al-
buminuria, diabetic nephropathy, and kidney disease
(outcomes). The full search strategy performed in
PubMed is presented in
Table S1 (please see the
Supporting Information online). The last search was
run on July 2020.
Selection of studies
Records were screened by title and
sections.abstract:
in a biblio-
graphic database (EndNote X9.3.1, Clarivate Analytics)
on the basis of the eligibility criteria, by 3 independent
investigators (I.E., J.B., and I.C.K.) after automatic ex-
clusion of duplicates. Records were also screened
through citation tracking and hand-searching of the ref-
erence lists for potentially eligible studies. To identify
eligible articles from the gray literature, we searched the
US National Library of Medicine (ClinicalTrials.gov)
and OpenGrey. After exclusion of obviously irrelevant
records, full-text articles were independently assessed
for eligibility through a standardized electronic form in
Google Forms
VR
by each investigator (I.E., J.B., and
I.C.K.). Disagreements between reviewers were resolved
by F.M.S.
Data collection
Data were independently extracted by 3 reviewers
grouped in 2 pairs (I.E. and J.B.; I.E. and I.C.K.)
through a standardized electronic form in Google
Forms
VR
and subsequently cross-checked in conjunction
with F.M.S. before computing entries in structured
tables in Microsoft Office Word
VR
. The following data
were extracted from each study: main author; year of
publication; study design; country of study; length of in-
tervention; measured end points; inclusion and exclu-
sion criteria; sample size (male/female ratio); age and
ethnicity; baseline values of body mass index (BMI) and
glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c); duration of diabetes and
frequency of each type of diabetes. Detailed descriptions

change for white meat (chicken or fish) or plant protein

of each intervention were also extracted, as well as be-
fore and after measurements of the primary outcomes.
Assessment of risk of bias in included studies
Risk of bias within individual trials was assessed by 2 in-
dependent investigators (I.E. and F.M.S.) using
Cochrane’s revised tool (RoB 2),
27 and final judgements
were established by consensus. Each study was evalu-
ated with regards to the 5 following domains: (1) bias
arising from the randomization process; (2) bias due to
deviations from intended interventions; (3) bias due to
missing outcome data; (4) bias in measurement of the
outcome; (5) bias in selection of the reported result.
Risk of bias judgements were: (A) low risk of bias; (B)
some concerns; and (C) high risk of bias. If an individ-
ual domain was judged to be at a particular level of risk
of bias, then the overall risk of bias for that study was
considered to be at least this severe. Since the current
review aims to quantify the effect of adhering to inter-
ventions (the “per-protocol effect”), deviations from
intended interventions are particularly concerning and
may therefore represent high risk of bias.
GRADE assessment of the quality of the evidence
The overall certainty in the evidence across studies was
assessed following the GRADE approach.
28 For each in-
dividual outcome, the quality of the evidence was con-
sidered “high” by default and thereafter downgraded to
“moderate”, “low”, or “very low” depending on the 5
following criteria: within-study risk of bias, directness
of evidence, heterogeneity, precision of effect estimates,
and risk of publication bias.
Data synthesis and analysis
Meta-analyses were performed using a DerSimonian
and Laird random-effects model with 95% confidence
intervals (CIs), even in the absence of statistical hetero-
geneity, assuming that there is not one single true effect
size (ie, the effect size varies from study to study) due to
the expected diversity between studies in terms of inter-
vention protocols. Meta-analyses are separately pre-
sented and interpreted by study design (as advised in
the Cochrane Handbook, Section 23.2.6) because (a)
crossover trials are artificially underweighted in com-
bined meta-analyses when these studies present out-
come data as if they arose from a parallel group design;
and (b) parallel trials were essentially designed as prag-
matic studies, and not explanatory proof-of-concept
investigations.
25 All analyses were conducted using sta-
tistical packages implemented in R version 3.6.2 (R
Project for Statistical Computing).
Studies reported UAE in 3 different units of mea-
surement that could not be interconverted (eg, albumin
excretion rates and albumin/creatinine ratio), which
precluded statistical analysis using the weighted mean
difference (WMD) as the treatment effect. The stan-
dardized mean difference (SMD), an alternative ap-
proach for combining results of different units, is not
only challenging to translate into clinically meaningful
information (because it requires knowledge of the
pooled SD) but may also indicate potentially misleading
results if the distribution of outcome values is highly
skewed, exhibiting some bias towards no effect.
29 Thus,
treatment effects are summarized by the ratio of the av-
erage treatment effect in the intervention group relative
to that of the control group. This relative effect, the ra-
tio of means (RoM), is comparable across different
units, has similar statistical performance characteristics
to mean difference methods and can be more readily
applied in a clinical context (a ratio of means of<1
favors intervention).
29–31 The results for GFR were also
analyzed and presented as a ratio of means. In order to
enhance the interpretability of the results, pooled esti-
mates for GFR were also presented as WMDs of post-
treatment values.
32
Assessment of heterogeneity, sensitivity analysis, and
publication bias
The magnitude of statistical heterogeneity was assessed
using the I
2 test, with values from 30% to 50% repre-
senting moderate, and /C21 50% representing substantial
heterogeneity. To identify potential sources of heteroge-
neity (whenever anI
2 of at least 40% was observed), ex-
ploratory subgroup analyses were performed based on:
(A) length of interventions (comparing short-term ver-
sus long-term studies, adopting 5 weeks as the cut-off
point), (B) whether food was provided or prescribed
only, (C) within-study risk of bias (ie, high or not high
risk), (D) severity of baseline albuminuria (comparison
of studies that recruited normoalbuminuric patients
versus the remaining studies), and (E) specific type of
protein under study. For outcomes with 10 or more
reports, funnel plots were used to assess the risk for
publication bias and small-study effects.
Trial sequential analysis
Trial Sequential Analysis (TSA) was used to assess
whether the available evidence was sufficiently powered
to support definitive
sections.conclusions:
33 using the TSA soft-
ware 0.9.5.10 Beta (Centre for Clinical Intervention
Research Department, Copenhagen, Denmark).

RESULTS
Study selection and description of the studies
Twelve studies
34–45 were selected for inclusion in this
systematic review. The initial search yielded a total of
12 197 records combined, of which 2562 were dupli-
cates. After screening the remaining 9635 records by ti-
tle and abstract, 18 articles were selected for full-text
assessment of eligibility. Of those, 6 studies were dis-
carded because they did not meet the inclusion criteria.
No additional relevant studies were identified in the
gray literature or other search methods. Interrater
agreement in the final judgement for study inclusion
was substantial (88.89% agreement; Cohen’sj ¼0.72).
A flowchart of the study selection process with reasons
for exclusion is presented in
Fig. 1.
Table 234–45 presents the main characteristics of
each study and its participants. Publications were all
available in English, dated from 1994 to 2017. With
regards to geographic location, 4 studies
34,39,41,43 were
conducted in Brazil, 436–38,40 in the USA, 2 in Iran,42,44
1i nG e r m a n y ,45 and 1 in Greece.35 Eight studies34–36,38–41,44
were crossover trials with 2 and 8 weeks as shortest and
longest intervention periods, respectively. Regarding
the 4 parallel trials, 2 were of relatively short duration
(6 and 12 weeks),
37,44 while the other 2 had substantially
longer (12 months and 4 years)42,43 follow-up periods.
A total of 318 participants were randomized across
12 studies, of which 239 were included in statistical
analyses because most studies reported a per-protocol
analysis only, excluding patients that dropped out of the
study or did not sufficiently comply with the protocol.
Sample sizes ranged from 8 to 53 patients. The mean
age of the participants ranged from 32.0 to 64.3 years,
mean BMI ranged from 23.2 to 35.1 kg/m
2, and time
since diagnosis of diabetes ranged from an average 5.0
to 14.0 years across studies. Two studies

sections.discussion:
In this systematic review of 12 studies (n¼318), inter-
ventions aimed at modifying the type of dietary protein
were associated with statistically significant reductions
in UAE. Results from parallel-design trials, as opposed
to crossover trials, were nonsignificant and lacked sta-
tistical power due to the limited number of studies
(n ¼3). Similarly, pooled results for GFR have shown
statistically significant reductions in the intervention
groups among crossover studies, but not in those of
parallel design. Subgroup analyses were unable to satis-
factorily explain differences in the effect estimate or sta-
tistical heterogeneity, with nonsignificant tests of
interaction and no substantial changes in the magnitude
of association. Most trials were judged as at least having
some concerns with regards to risk of bias, and the
quality of the evidence was very limited.
This is the first systematic review of RCTs to evalu-
ate the effects of different sources of dietary protein on
markers of kidney function in patients with diabetes.
Previous meta-analyses of RCTs have shown beneficial
effects of higher soy protein consumption on serum
creatinine, phosphorus, and proteinuria in predialysis
patients with CKD.
24 In the most recent clinical practice
guidelines by the Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality
Initiative (KDOQI) for nutrition in CKD,
recommendations regarding the source of dietary pro-
tein were limited to effects on nutritional status, cal-
cium and phosphorus levels, and the blood lipid
profile.
47 Due to insufficient evidence at the time, there
was no recommendation for a particular protein type in
adults at any stage of CKD for clinical outcomes or
parameters of kidney function.
The rationale for qualitatively manipulating the
type of protein has been largely based on the reduction
of glomerular hyperfiltration, which potentially protects
from hyalinosis, proteinuria, and further kidney dam-
age. Some of the postulated mechanisms involve reduc-
tion of the expression of renin–angiotensin (slowing the
progression of CKD through favorable effects on GFR),
reduction in serum phosphate and FGF-23 levels, as
well as a reduction in the phosphorus load that is asso-
ciated with food items from animal sources.
48,49 In ad-
dition, certain amino acids such as alanine, glycine, and
arginine have been shown to induce glomerular hyper-
filtration, which could also be partially responsible for
the effects of red meat consumption on kidney func-
tion.
21,23,50 On the other hand, soy-based diets seem to
reduce blood pressure and to reduce plasma and renal
angiotensin-converting enzyme activity, possibly
through the actions of isoflavones.
51 It is also possible
that favorable effects of soy consumption on diabetic
nephropathy can be partially explained by its impact on
serum cholesterol, although interpretation of the avail-
able evidence is susceptible to confounding due to
intercorrelation between risk factors.
52 It is still unclear
which of the underlying mechanisms are most likely to
mediate the beneficial effects of dietary factors on kid-
ney parameters; however, because foods and nutrients
are not consumed in isolation, it is likely that any true
benefit arises from a variety of simultaneous biological
pathways.
Further compounding the “dietary-protein-type
hypothesis” is the notion of dietary patterns, which
reflects the variety of foods that represent habitual die-
tary intake. Diets typically characterized by a reduced
intake of animal or red meat protein (eg, dietary pat-
terns such as the Mediterranean diet and the Dietary
Approaches to Stop Hypertension, also known as
DASH), focusing on plant proteins and fish, are consid-
ered dietary patterns with multifactorial beneficial
health effects.
53,54 In epidemiological studies, adherence
to these dietary patterns is consistently associated with
decreased risk of disease progression and improved
markers of kidney function.
55–58 However, whether
such dietary patterns affect albuminuria and DKD pro-
gression remains unclear. Recently, Banerjee et al
reported observational evidence on the potential bene-
fits associated with adherence to a DASH dietary pat-
tern on the risk of progression to end-stage renal

Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/nutritionreviews/article/80/4/812/6335545 by guest on 08 February 2024

disease among adults with moderate CKD and hyper-
tension.
59 Compared with the highest quintile of adher-
ence to a DASH diet, the lowest quintile was associated
with a 1.7-fold risk of end-stage renal disease (relative
hazard, 1.7; 95% CI, 1.1 to 2.7), with greater magnitude
of association in patients with diabetes in subgroup
analysis. A similar pattern of results was shown in the
first prospective community-based cohort to report
associations between plant-based diets and risk of GFR
decline and CKD in the general population.
60 In this
study, Kim et al demonstrated that higher adherence to
a healthy plant-based diet (higher consumption of
fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, and legumes) was
associated with lower risk of CKD (HR, 0.86; 95% CI,
0.78 to 0.96) and slower GFR decline. While there
seems to be no unequivocal evidence to suggest that
such diets are causally related to outcomes and favor-
ably affect relevant clinical end points, patterns of eating
that are associated with improvements in blood pres-
sure, body weight and other cardiorenal risk factors
have been incorporated in the nutrition therapy of indi-
viduals with DKD.
61
Owing to highly diverse methodological and clini-
cal aspects across studies, it should be noted that the
presence of an effect as well as its magnitude may be de-
pendent on several key aspects. First, it is possible that
patients with a diagnosis of DKD may respond differ-
ently compared with individuals at risk of kidney dis-
ease (ie, normal kidney function). Futhermore, among
individuals with diagnosed kidney disease, the severity
of renal impairment may also play an important role in
modifying the effects of different types of dietary pro-
tein. Thus, heterogeneity in the final results could be
partly explained due to pathophysiological differences
between patients with normal renal function, with mild
impairment, with severe impairment, or undergoing he-
modialysis. Indeed, the effects of anti-albuminuric ther-
apies are often more pronounced in patients with overt
albuminuria compared with those with microalbuminu-
ria; and in patients with microalbuminuria compared
with those with normoalbuminuria.
31 Although an at-
tempt was made to perform subgroup analyses based on
severity of albuminuria at baseline as a proxy measure-
ment for severity of pre-existing renal impairment, it
still remains as a limitation to the interpretation of the
current meta-analysis given the inconclusive results
produced by exploratory analyses, as well as the fact
that the primary studies often included patients with
varying degrees of renal impairment (resulting in
within-study diversity on top of between-study diver-
sity), an issue that would only have been possible to
overcome by performing individual participant data
meta-analyses.
Second, the observed effects of different interven-
tions on renal function may depend on the nature of
their specific biological mechanisms. For instance, the
reduction of red meat intake itself might promote bene-
ficial effects independently of the type of dietary protein
it is exchanged for. In this case, it is possible that differ-
ences between groups correspond to the combined
effects of withdrawing certain types of protein (eg, red
meat or any animal meat) in addition to implementing
other types of protein. Third, the degree of adherence
to interventions should not be overlooked. Some trials
provided food to the free-living subjects, but most stud-
ies have not sufficiently described whether all the food
was eaten, nor attempted to quantitatively report the
adherence to the specific protein sources of each inter-
vention arm. Even when subjects are extensively
instructed to only consume the food provided by the
investigators, it is often the case that substantial quanti-
ties of off-study food are consumed (eg, consumption
of other protein sources in addition to the planned
interventions).
62 In this sense, it is possible that the in-
tervention arms were at risk of overconsuming the
expected amount of animal or red meat protein, poten-
tially confounding the final results towards the null.
Although most studies included in this systematic re-
view have been quantitatively assessed and excellent ad-
herence to the total protein intake was guaranteed,
placing a restriction on some type of dietary protein
(and consequently on several food items in an otherwise
usual diet for most patients) may lead to unintended
reductions in the overall protein intake in real-world
settings, where adherence to recommendations is a
common issue, which indicates care would be needed
in clinical application.
Subgroup analyses did not give meaningful results
because of the low number of studies with comparable
design and due to the diversity in methodological and
clinical aspects. For this reason, inferences regarding
any one subgroup comparison are extremely limited as
a result of there being many other competing explana-
tions for the observed differences. For instance, among
crossover trials that provided food items for patients,
other study-level covariates were also highly diverse,
such as adherence to the protocol, baseline severity of
albuminuria, and differences in the intervention proto-
cols (eg, different food sources of dietary protein across
studies). Ideally, studies should be similar enough so
that only a few biological or methodological aspects
would be plausible candidates for explaining between-
study heterogeneity. Thus, diversity of multiple aspects
across studies limits the ability to pinpoint to what ex-
tent each coviariate was responsible for the observed
differences in results. For this reason, results from

subgroup and sensitivity analyses were unable to accu-
rately explain inconsistencies between studies.
The body of evidence consists of few trials of small
sample sizes (range, 8 to 53), which may lead to poten-
tially biased estimates due to the meta-analytical phe-
nomenon of small-study effects.
63 Although funnel
plots were not compatible with risk of publication bias,
small-study effects are often associated with selective
reporting and inflated effects due to poor methodologi-
cal quality.
64 Furthermore, formal GRADE assessment
revealed multiple reasons for rating down the quality of
the evidence. First, only one study was judged as being
at low risk of bias, whereas the majority of studies were
considered as being at high risk. The most frequent po-
tential source of bias were deviations from intended
interventions, which is particularly concerning given
that nonadherence to the experimental diet tends to
generate bias towards the null, as previously noted. Out
of all the studies, only Azadbakht, 2008
42 and
Azadbakht, 200944 attempted to quantify and report the
adherence to the type of protein under study. Second,
results are presented with unexplained statistical hetero-
geneity in light of the highly diverse trials, representing
substantial inconsistency. Third, the small number of
studies and sample sizes, as well as the large patient-
level variability in outcome measurements, have led to
relatively imprecise effect estimates. In addition, it is
possible that artificially large CIs were created due to a
unit-of-analysis error: as we were unable to extract
paired data that appropriately accounted for the within-
individual treatment comparisons (due to incomplete
reporting in the primary studies), the meta-analyses
were conducted as if individuals (not treatments) had
been randomized and analyzed as parallel-design, which
is likely to have resulted in poor precision.
65,66 On the
other hand, strengths of this systematic review process
should be noted. This study was strictly based on the
latest Cochrane recommendations, while following
PRISMA guidelines for a prospectively registered proto-
col. Furthermore, the assessment of within-study risk of
bias was performed using rigorous methods under the
strict guidance of the RoB 2 revised tool to assess risk of
bias in randomized trials. An attempt to overcome po-
tential limitations to the interpretability of findings was
presenting results in clinically relatable units. The use of
standardized mean differences as a measure of pooled
estimates is the most widely used approach when trials
have measured the same construct with different met-
rics; however, there are issues associated with (1) the
fact that patients and clinicians are unlikely to relate to
the results of effect sizes, (2) trials that enroll heteroge-
neous samples of patients yield smaller standardized
mean differences than those less heterogeneous, even if
the actual mean difference estimates are similar across
studies, and (3) very homogeneous populations of
patients give misleadingly inflated magnitudes of ef-
fect.
32 For those reasons, results are presented for both
UAE and GFR as ratios of postintervention means.
The available evidence herein summarized is insuf-
ficient to provide clear recommendations for clinical
practice due to the limited quality of the evidence and
should therefore be interpreted with caution. The po-
tential benefits of replacing animal protein or red meat
protein with other sources of dietary protein could be
interpreted in the context of emerging evidence sug-
gesting protective effects of certain dietary patterns, in
general, for cardiorenal patients, and for other health-
related outcomes. It is likely that adopting an approach
that shifts the focus onto foods rather than type of pro-
tein may be more beneficial for message translation, in-
tervention implementation, and consequently disease
management, and this should be addressed in prag-
matic trials (aiming to assess the effect of the method of
assignment of a patient to a particular intervention). On
the other hand, future proof-of-concept studies (aiming
to assess the effect of adhering to the intervention pro-
tocols) should be adequately powered to detect mean-
ingful but realistic differences in albuminuria and GFR;
include patients with relatively homogeneous baseline
levels of albuminuria, and establish means of enhancing
the adherence of patients to the planned protocol con-
cerning the type of dietary protein, while adequately ac-
counting for between-group differences in the
consumption of nutrients other than the specific pro-
teins under study. Although findings from TSA suggest
that the available evidence for GFR can be considered
conclusive, the assessment of the quality of the evidence
supports the conclusion that further trials are likely to
modify the current effect estimates .
CONCLUSION
This meta-analysis shows weak evidence for small to
moderate improvements in markers of kidney function
in favor of interventions with lower animal protein (or
red meat protein) compared with usual diets in short-
term crossover trials. Data on long-term studies are
scarce, and most trials were at high risk of bias. Due to
the limited quality of the evidence, these findings re-
quire further confirmation in well-designed random-
ized controlled trials.
